admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents a performance audit
            of the First Education Project for Ireland and is based in
            part on the Project Completion Report (PCR). The audit
            agrees with the analysis and findings of the PCR and adds
            comments on project generation. The project has been
            successfully implemented with the exception of the following
            changes: (a) the transfer of the College of Commerce to the
            Second Education Project; (b) the deletion of the 30
            agricultural education centers and their construction
            outside of the project; (c) the substitution of eight new
            comprehensive schools in place of seven of those which had
            been included in the project as approved; and (d) non-use of
            the technical assistance provided for educational facility
            planning. These changes reflected the need for more advanced
            project preparation involving discussion with local
            authorities during the project generation stage. However,
            project objectives remained intact. Physical implementation
            was generally well attended to. The project's community
            schools are operating with average efficiency within Ireland
            and are making proportional contributions to the labor
            market and to the supply of students for higher education
            institutions. Other highlights of this report include: (a)
            the use of architectural design competition to select school
            designs; (b) the progressive refinement of school building
            and furniture designs; (c) some flaws in school design and
            construction regarding thermal insulation, roofing, and
            sub-floor drainage; (d) the over-supply of teachers in the
            schools by comparison with appraisal estimates; (e) the
            strategy of using smaller class sizes and a larger number of
            class groups than envisaged at appraisal; (f) the very
            strong community participation and support; (g) the
            enrollment in community schools reflecting the
            socio-economic composition of their catchment areas; (h) and
            the good performance of the Department of Education's
            Project Unit in portions falling within that Department, but
            its ineffectiveness in coping with portions falling within
            the Department of Agriculture.
